awd_titl_txt: UNS: U.S.-China: Systems-Based Approaches for Sustainable Steel Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
1510531  
Bras, Bert 

This U.S. - China project will create a systems-based approach to reducing environmental impacts of manufacturing. The approach will be centered on design and operation of eco-industrial parks (EIPs). The methods to be developed focus on systems-based modeling and analysis in order to understand and manage the complexity of sustainable manufacturing. The general approach is relevant to a wide variety of problems at different industrial scales. Thus, this research can help develop methods and approaches useful in many applications and both the U.S. and China will benefit from the expected findings in developing more sustainable economies. The U.S.- China research team will develop this systems-based approach with tools from plant to market scale in order to (a) improve the sustainability of manufacturing and (b) understand interactions across scales to identify synergies and constraints that affect the ability to enhance sustainability in production of manufactured products. 

Three research thrusts will be pursued. Thrust 1 is focused on the development of systems-based technology solutions at the plant scale to increase water, energy and material efficiency and reduce environmental impacts for manufacturing processes. This thrust involves data collection, model development and visualization of typical manufacturing processes and allows plant level comparisons of water, energy and material flows between the U.S. and China. Thrust 2 is focused on developing strategies for transforming manufacturing plants into eco-industrial parks by means of industrial symbiosis with other companies. Insights gained from ecological systems organization will be used to build industrial ecosystems at the eco-industrial park scale to increase the sustainability and resilience of manufacturing industries. In Thrust 3, an integrated framework coupling agent-based model and life-cycle assessment will be developed for evaluating the adoption of the solutions proposed at the plant and eco-industrial park scales from Thrusts 1 and 2.
 
A case study of focus is steel manufacturing because of the potential for significant potential positive environmental benefits. Reducing the environmental footprint of China's steelmaking directly improves the competitiveness of goods produced and sold by US companies with parts that are sourced from China. Focusing on the steel industry will provide immediate benefit to consumers, industries, and other stakeholders associated with steel production (which is fundamental to many industrial products), but the general approach is relevant to a wide variety of problems at different industrial scales. Traditional process engineering improvements will be considered in conjunction with the role of steel mills in eco-industrial park settings where other companies may receive synergistic benefits from process improvements. The combined effects will be evaluated at the market level using an agent-based modeling and life-cycle analysis framework. Such a multi-scale approach to achieving higher degrees of sustainable manufacturing is unique. The team will have unique cutting-edge access to the Chinese steel industry as well as eco-industrial parks in China. The insight gained from these Chinese eco-industrial parks (which are very capital intensive to set up) will be used to develop "best practices" that will be used to assess the benefits and costs of pursuing such parks in the U.S. around U.S. steel mills and other manufacturing companies. A comparison of environmentally sustainable steel manufacturing practices in both China and the U.S. will be made. Unique insights will be gained by coupling technology-related production decisions and policies to their effects on the market and environment by means of the integrated agent-based modeling and life-cycle analysis framework. The project will evaluate policies from the U.S. perspective in promoting the environmental sustainability of the Chinese steel industry. For example, the project will investigate whether the enforcement of strict environmental regulations for electrical products exported to the U.S. market will lead to a more environmentally sustainable steel industry in China or increase product demand from U.S. companies in this market, or both. The project will capitalize on the opportunity for collaboration between two different countries with different cultures, as well as different steel manufacturing technologies and leverage the project to develop new educational and outreach materials. The combined influence and size of the participating schools and organizations, and the multidisciplinary team provides a unique training opportunity. Inclusion of project methods and outcomes in coursework will have significant impact on the education of future engineers in the U.S. and China, and enhance their ability to solve complex challenges in sustainability.

This grant is co-funded by the Global Venture Fund (GVF) of NSF's International Science and Engineering section (ISE) and the CBET/ENG Environmental Sustainability program.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to investigate how novel approaches from engineering and biology can be used to reduce the environmental burdens and improve the sustainability of manufacturing processes, specifically steel manufacturing facilities, by: 1) optimizing the manufacturing process; 2) integrating the facility and its resource and waste flows in a larger urban-industrial ecosystem and eco-industrial park: and 3) identifying the impact on other economic sectors. Steel manufacturing, especially using blast oven furnaces like in the Chinese steel industry, is a significant contributor to global greenhouse gas emissions.

The aims of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, environmental impact and improving resource efficiency, were addressed by analyzing the manufacturing processes using traditional methods and metrics (such as financial cost, energy efficiency and water use). These approaches were augmented and combined with an approach called Ecological Network Analysis (ENA) that is used by ecologists to quantitatively analyze and study the performance and interactions within natural ecosystems and food webs in a holistic manner.

The research showed that traditional steel manufacturing processes using blast-oven furnaces (like found in the Chinese steel industry) have improved in resource efficiency over the past decades. Using ENA, it was found that higher resource utilization and efficiencies could still be achieved by co-locating other manufacturing facilities such as a cement plant and a construction material production plant near the main steel plant and creating an Eco-Industrial Park (EIP), which has the benefit of taking waste streams and converting them into useable materials and products elsewhere in the expanded manufacturing system.

This project examined the general issue of the benefits of optimizing industrial systems based upon both cost minimization and resource cycling. Detailed data on water flows in a generic Chinese steel plant were combined with ENA methods to examine cycling efficiency. The modeled steel plant was optimized to reduce costs. This was compared to a multi-criteria optimization model minimizing costs and maximizing water cycling. The multi-criteria model reduced costs to the same extent as the cost-optimized model while increasing the amount of water recycled by roughly a factor of five.

The project also investigated the impact of incorporating natural systems into the steel manufacturing ‘ecology’ for treating wastes. Specifically, the use of constructed wetlands in a steel manufacturing facility’s wastewater treatment was investigated. The inclusion of natural wetlands within the facility to treat water that is otherwise discarded as effluent from the steel manufacturing process resulted in major reductions of freshwater consumption, effluent generation, and cost.  The combination of these natural systems with traditional approaches resulted in reducing freshwater demand by hundreds of cubic meters per hour and saving several millions of dollars per year in operating costs. Furthermore, the plants growing in the wetland could be harvested and subjected to pyrolysis, a process that converts biomass into char. Analysis showed that incorporating this char as fuel for the steel plant coke oven would reduce coal demand by hundreds of kilograms per day. This case study shows that integration of natural systems into manufacturing is possible and can provide environmental and financial benefits.

These results challenge the perspective that reducing cost and enhancing cycling are tradeoffs, and corroborate claims of improved efficiencies by incorporating within industrial systems actors that act analogously to ‘decomposers’ in natural systems, which return previously unusable components to the system so they may be reused. Further, this case study serves as an example of how the decomposer role found in natural systems can be embodied through biological systems paired with industry to provide enhanced efficiency and lower costs. This study provides evidence that including natural systems as part of a manufacturing facility may be an innovative and effective way to achieve significant process improvements over traditional process optimizations, leading to more sustainable manufacturing with lower greenhouse gas and pollutant emissions to the environment, which ultimately improves human well-being.

The results indicate that our human designed systems still have a lot of potential for improvement with respect to resource flows and management when compared with natural food webs and ecosystems. The results also indicate that combining urban and industrial systems, and their infrastructures, may lead to better performance than merely focusing on optimizing individual systems. The integration of natural systems (like constructed wetlands) into urban and industrial systems can offer additional opportunities for resource savings and sustainability improvements.

The project positively and directly impacted society by pursuing research to reduce environmental impacts of large-scale manufacturing processes while increasing their effectiveness, creating economic and ecological win-win situations. As shown, there is potential for substantial cost and resource savings in large scale manufacturing processes when one includes opportunities for waste reuse, especially when drawing upon natural systems. This has the potential to position American manufacturing in a more competitive and sustainable position in the world economy, which will benefit U.S. citizens and society at large.
